text: let's see error detection let's start
the session with the outcome in today's
session we have four outcomes upon the
completion of the session the learner
will be able to outcome number one
understand transmission errors outcome
number two we will know the types of
errors outcome number three we will
understand error detection and error
correction process and the last outcome
we will know the various error detection
techniques let's start the session with
what is an error in a computer network
obviously data are transmitted in the
network when the data are transmitted
over the network we don't know what
happens to the data once the data has
left the node so the data can be
corrupted during transmission so the
errors that are caused because of this
transmission are called as transmission
error and for reliable communication
these errors must be detected and
corrected in which layer the error
related things are handled actually
invoice a reference model there are two
layers that deal with error control
error detection and correction an
implementer either at the data link
layer or the transport layer of the OSI
model just recollect the OSI reference
model and the services offered by each
layer in data link layer as well as in
the transport layer we have error
control as one of the services of those
layers now let's see what are the types
of errors we have basically two types of
error number one bit error and number
two burst error we will start with what
is a bit error
a bit error only one bit is going to be
changed so it is also known as single
bit error and in a single bit error only
one bit in the data unit has been
changed we will understand this with
this example in this scenario this is
the sender side and let this be the
receiver side and the sender is sending
0 0 0 0 0 0 1 0 but upon reception the
receiver is receiving 0 0 0 0 1 0 1 0 if
you notice here this bit has been
changed as 1 we can notice here the
sender is sending some information but
the receiver is receiving a different
information and there is a change in
exactly one bit when there is only one
bit change we will call it as a bit
error whereas if there are group of bits
that are changed then we will call it as
a burst error let's see burst error now
in burst error two or more bits in the
data units have we changed let's see
suppose if this is the information that
the sender is sending and this is what
the receiver is receiving we can notice
that there are some bits that are
corrupted the sender has sent 0 here but
the receiver is receiving 1 here and
this 0 here but the receiver is
receiving 1 here and these 2 bits are
also changed now when we calculate the
length of the corrupted bits it is not 1
2 3 & 4 the length of the burst error is
8 bits because this is for the entire
length of the corrupted bits it is 1 2 3
4 5 6 7 8 bits so far we have seen what
is an error and the types of error now
let's see how to detect these errors
generally error detection will be done
by the receiver it means the receiver
has to decide whether the received data
is correct or not without having a copy
of the original message the receiver
normally will not be having original
message because the original message
itself has been corrupted by
transmission errors now how to detect
these errors when we send only original
message it's very difficult for the
receiver to understand or to know
whether there is an error or not so with
the message some additional information
have to be sent by the sender so that
these additional information will help
the receiver to understand or to find
out whether there is an error or not in
the data that is being transmitted so to
detect or correct errors we need to send
some extra bits with the data and these
extra bits are called as redundant bits
let's see what is redundant bits that is
redundancy now in redundancy suppose if
this is the sender side if this is the
receiver side if sender has this data to
be sent the sender gives the data to the
generating function or an algorithm and
this algorithm generates a code which we
call as the redundant code or redundant
bits or redundancy check and this
information is appended with the message
that has to be sent and this is the
message which is here and this
redundancy check or the redundant bits
are added with the message and that
means just appended and the whole
information is now sent to the receiver
the receiver message two parts in the
message one is the original message and
the other one is the redundant bits so
he takes this original message and the
checking function in the receiver side
this is also an algorithm it calculates
redundant bits it compares the redundant
bits with the redundant bits that was
sent by the sender if both are matching
then the receiver understands that there
are no errors in the transmission so it
accepts it otherwise the receiver
rejects this so far we have seen how to
detect errors now let's see error
correction briefly
error detection means it's the job of
the receiver to detect the error if it
is there it will discard it otherwise it
will accept it error detection is very
simple just accept or reject
whereas error correction is a tedious
job the receiver has to correct the
errors it can be handled in two ways
number one the receiver can have the
sender retransmit the entire data unit
if the receiver detects the error it can
ask the sender to retransmit the entire
information or the receiver can use an
error correcting code which
automatically corrects certain errors
but when we talk about error detection
and error correction and a detection is
normally a simple task but error
correction is somewhat difficult now
let's see whether error detection and
error correction needs redundancy yes
both error detection and error
correction needs redundancy why because
without additional information it's very
difficult to detect or correct the
errors so when the sender sends the data
or the message there will be a generator
or some algorithm to generate the
redundancy and this redundant
information and the message are
generally sent over an unreliable
transmission medium we are saying it as
an unreliable medium because it is prone
to errors and the receiver receives this
information whatever the receiver
receives it gives that information to
the checker and this checker says
whether to accept the data or reject a
data or whether to correct the data or
discount the data correcting means this
checker part tells which part is
affected with errors and it can be
corrected discarding means simply
discarding the packet and we can ask the
sender to retransmit and the message is
finally received by the receiver in
today's lecture we are focusing only on
error detection and what are the various
ways to do error detection there are
basically four ways four types of
redundancy checks or techniques that are
used in data communications and they are
number one vertical redundancy check
which is simply called as VRC number two
longitudinal redundancy check simply lrc
number three checksum or Internet
checksum or arithmetic checksum and the
last one is cyclic redundancy check
which is CRC
in the previous lectures we have seen
some protocols in the data link
Claire which uses error detection
techniques some protocol uses CRC and
some protocol uses checksum these two
are very familiar in protocols and
that's it guys I hope now you understood
transmission errors now you know the
types of errors bit errors and burst
errors and you understand the difference
between error detection and error
correction and know the various error
detection techniques we RC LRC checksum
and CRC I hope you guys have enjoyed the
lecture and thank you for watching
